answers.text: @captain.freddie And here is, what is problematic about this narrative. Sure, not all Germans were Nazis. But a big majority just was. The students around Hans and Sophie Scholl celebrated a party after the members of the WeiÃŸe Rose were arrested. Because the enemy once again was fought. Sophie hoped for an uprise in Germany after her death. But no such thing happened. Most of the Germans continued being Nazis, supporting their actions, fighting their war, persecuting Jews, Sinti and Roma people, mentally and physically disabled people. There is no such thing as relief in the story of Sophie Scholl.

Thank you Jesper. I really appreciate your post. I totally agree, that more stories should be trading this dark heritage, so it will be remembered and hopefully never happen again!
It is a relief that you take awareness, that not all of the Germans are fck Nazis.
